Death is already tragic. Just like #gold, I‚Äôve always understood the importance to protect people‚Äôs digital assets, to provide them a way to pass #Bitcoin onto the next generation, w/o losing them to lost passwords or passphrases.\nPlease take steps to NOT lose Bitcoin upon death.

Though my grandfather never bought #Bitcoin, he owned small amounts I gave him physically via BTCC Mint coins and @BalletCrypto REAL wallets. It really needs to be that easy for people of his age.\n\nNow that he‚Äôs passed away, he won‚Äôt take his #Bitcoins with him; NOT lost forever.

When I started @BalletCrypto last year, I clearly had my grandfather in mind. Real people, regardless of age, have true difficulties remembering passwords, and I wanted to invent a new kind of #crypto wallet that even my grandfather could use: a #BearerAsset Wallet => Ballet.

My grandfather is THE original #GoldBug in our Lee family. Without him, my father probably would not have been a #gold trader, and my bother @SatoshiLite and I probably wouldn‚Äôt be gold bugs either.\n\nOur interests and passion in #Bitcoin today traces back to my grandfather.

He taught all Lee Family members the true value of #Gold. He & grandma, recently married & pregnant with their 1st child, daringly escaped Shanghai in 1949 by taking steamer to Hong Kong, avoiding the imminent communist invasion. He took with him Gold bars sewn into his clothing.

I just remembered he even showed us movies using those (16mm?) film projectors, and eventually gifted me my first VHS camera recorder. He had such influence on all of us. I was his eldest grandson, and many say he naturally loved me the most. I miss him dearly. I‚Äôm grieving.

My fondest childhood memory in Africa was sitting on his lap, behind the steering wheels of his Mercedes-Benz, with him teaching me how to steer and drive. He also got me interested in photography at a young age with his various #Polaroid cameras. He was a gadget guy, and me too.

My grandfather William Lee just passed away peacefully tonight, surrounded by his family. He was 95 years old. On this #MothersDay, he gets to go join our great-grandmother & our late grandmother. I‚Äôm glad I got to see him in person one last time & held his hand this afternoon.üò≠

Until then, we'll continue to answer every question with as much specificity and transparency as possible.\n\nThank you @nvk for bringing up this important topic, and I look forward to having more of these discussions with you and other experts.

We're open to suggestions from security experts & other vendors, about how best to perform a comprehensive security audit of our multinational two-factor key generation & manufacturing process. \n\nWe would pay for travel and expenses for a qualified expert(s) to conduct an audit.

We have yet to find an established & reputable standards organization that can conduct this type of audit, to issue a certification that is recognized by the cryptocurrency industry.\n\nThis isn‚Äôt only a challenge for us, but for every company in the industry.

I ran a major exchange for 5 years (BTCChina @YourBTCC) and manufactured 22,000+ physical bitcoins at BTCC Mint (loaded with 8,700+ BTC), with no security failures.\n\nA qualified auditor would at least need to have this kind of private key security experience as I do.

We haven't had an independent security audit yet.\n\nWe're currently unaware of any qualified experts who publicly offer this service. We reached out to traditional certification entities like ISO-9000; they declined b/c they're not qualified (no experience) to evaluate our process

If we published the results of a successful audit, wouldn't the critics just move the goalposts and accuse us of generating the keys differently when the auditor isn't watching?\n\nNevertheless, we're committed to maximum transparency, so long as it doesn't put security at risk. https://t.co/2qWr15h3uO

A 100% offline cold storage solution for Bitcoin that is simple enough for virtually anyone age 9 to 99 to use. No computer setup required, no passwords, no KYC, impossible to hack, and future-proof. In addition, @BalletCrypto wallets are elegant & aesthetically pleasing. Enjoy!

I founded @BalletCrypto to make Bitcoin easy and safe for everyone, even people with limited computer aptitude (most of the world). In my opinion, using Bitcoin means holding your own private keys, not relying on a third-party to hold your coins. That's why I decided to build...

I believe people thrive in a society that maximizes individual liberty and property rights. I have devoted my time & effort to Bitcoin over the past 9 yrs because it enables that kind of society. However, Bitcoin's technical complexity is a barrier to entry for most of the world.

@TerencesTweets The difference between Centralized and Decentralized is NOT about who or how many parties are INVOLVED. \n\nRather, it‚Äôs about whether someone or some group of people is in control with a MASTER KEY.

By the way, adding a checksum hash does NOT automatically make it immutable or permanent.\n\nAs long as the #LinkedList data structure is centrally managed (even if in a distributed computing environment), the system owner can always go back, make changes, and recompute all hashes.

Remember, before #Blockchain (invented by #Bitcoin in 2009), there already was the #LinkedList data structure, which links together blocks of data. And optionally, in each block data, you can add a hash of the previous block, to easily detect tampering. This was all before 2009!
